abstracts.cdata!:
The ratings for the State Health Systems
            Development Project for India were as follows: the outcome
            was satisfactory, the sustainability was likely, the
            institutional development impact was substantial, and the
            Bank and borrower performance were both satisfactory. The
            lessons learned indicate that a close link between health
            system improvements, policy and institutional reforms on one
            hand, and achieving desired health outcomes on the other
            hand, should be better reflected in project design and be
            monitored accordingly. Regular policy dialogue to address
            the problem of low public financing for the health sector is
            extremely important. It is important to sharpen focus of the
            public sector on service priorities in terms of both
            resources and management. Facilitate development and more
            engagement of private health sector in delivery of health
            care to achieve Millennium Development Goals (MDGs) is
            necessary. The commitment of the government and the
            political will for the support of the health project/sector
            and the reforms played a vital role in the project's
            achievements. Measuring and monitoring performance is
            critical for management decisions and to ensure high impact
            of project activities on the health sector. Development
            objectives should be clearly defined and measurable. Another
            lesson learnt is the need to have properly trained financial
            management staff in place right from the beginning of the
            project to ensure full financial accountability and adequate follow-up.
